item.title: Increasing graffiti, 19th January
item.description:
Hello Bromley from a Street Friend, I appreciate the increasing graffiti here is on a BT telephone exchange building but can the council do anything or enter dialogue with BT to get this removed? This started last year and is looking really unsightly now, and the longer it is left other vandals are adding more to it. Thanks as ever for any help you can give :o)

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Crystal Palace Park Road, Crystal Palace, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Solid bollard hit by vehicle again, 19th January
item.description:
A bollard that appeared in last year's waterworks disruption has been hit again in last two weeks and someone has put behind utilities cabinet but still cables sticking out and enormous trip hazard! Note - MY x house mate reported last one not sure who with but was fixed in 4 hours, !

item.title: Extremely poor road surface condition with potholes and debris, 19th January
item.description:
Dear Sir / Madam, The road surface has significantly deteriorated here and is now clearly unsafe. There are widespread potholes, loose aggregate, exposed sub-layers, and standing water, indicating structural failure rather than minor surface defects. Temporary patch repairs are no longer an adequate or reasonable response and a complete resurface is necessary. The condition has worsened further due to ongoing construction at Little Birches. Frequent use by heavy construction vehicles and the repeated deposition of mud and rubble have accelerated surface breakdown, with no visible mitigation or remedial measures in place. This issue has been raised several times previously, yet no permanent solution or resurfacing plan has been communicated. Harland Avenue is a busy residential road serving families, school routes, and elderly residents. Leaving it in its current condition presents an ongoing safety risk and raises concerns regarding the authorityâ€™s duty of care. I request: 1. Confirmation of the most recent formal inspection 2. An explanation for the continued absence of a resurfacing decision 3. A clear timeline for full resurfacing, not temporary repairs I truely hope this request is reviewed and the much needed action is promptly taken in this matter. Yours sincerely. Regards.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 43, Harland Avenue, Longlands, Sidcup, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Prince of Wales Rd Junction with Malden Road, 19th January
item.description:
Three things:- 1) Dangerously deep and hazard pothole on carriageway, which warrants prioritisation from your contractor 2) Cycle markings have worn away 3) Debris from the potholes is across the cycleway and is creating a skid hazard for all road users

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 1, Malden Road, Chalk Farm, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet
